keyTakeAways: Richard Kenneth Djerf was executed in Arizona on October 18, 2025, for the 1993 murder of four members of the Luna family in Phoenix.
The execution marked Arizona’s second execution of the year and the 39th death row execution in 2025, emphasizing ongoing use of the death penalty despite past controversies.

Djerf, who had been in prison for over 29 years, claimed he killed the family in revenge for an alleged theft involving electronics and a gun, and sexually assaulted the daughter before killing all four family members.

The execution process took about 10 minutes, with a few attempts due to poor vein conditions, and was conducted without incident, though Arizona has previously faced criticism for slow IV insertion times.
The state has faced repeated criticism over its execution practices, including a botched 2014 execution of Joseph Wood, which prompted a hiatus and a broader review of capital punishment procedures.
The 2024 review, ended by Governor Katie Hobbs firing an appointed examiner, led to changes in the execution team and protocols, enabling the resumption of executions.
Arizona now has 107 prisoners on death row, with five more executions scheduled in the U.S. in 2025, including in Florida, Alabama, Oklahoma, and Tennessee.
The execution of Djerf was supported by Attorney General Kris Mayes, who stated that the victims’ loved ones deserve closure and that justice is being served.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Richard Kenneth Djerf, 55, was executed in Phoenix, Arizona, on October 18, 2025, for the 1993 killing of four members of the Luna family — Albert Luna Sr., Patricia Luna, 18-year-old Rochelle Luna, and 5-year-old Damien Luna — after being driven by a false belief that a family member had stolen property. The execution, the second in Arizona that year, followed a 29-year prison sentence and was conducted without incident despite technical challenges in IV placement. The case is significant not only for the crime’s brutality and the long duration of the legal process but also for the broader context of Arizona’s controversial and repeatedly criticized death penalty practices, including a botched 2014 execution and multiple pauses due to public and political scrutiny. The state has since implemented procedural reforms, and with Djerf’s execution, Arizona now has 107 prisoners on death row. The article reflects ongoing debates about the morality, efficiency, and human cost of capital punishment in the United States.
title: Arizona Executes Man for 1993 Phoenix Family Murders in Act of Revenge
